column4: hey guys, this book I'm reading is saying that an operating system cannot boot properly if the boot info is kept "above the hard drive's 1023rd cylinder". Anyone knows what that means?
some older computers require the kernel to be placed toward the beginning of the HDD  (fyi drive space is broken up into cylinders)
so that would not really apply to a machine that can support SLI right?
probably not.  The proof is whether your system boots

the reason I ask is because I was trying to install ubuntu using two harddrives, one was a 20gb drive while the other was a 200GB sata drive. mounted the 20G drive as the root partition and the rest on the sata drive and when I was done it didnt boot
was I being realistic in setting it up this way?
I would think so.  you should post what errors you ran into
error 15
does it say file not found?
yes, I think so, it would get up to GRUB stage 1.5 and then the error showed up
well, sounds like you may have a bad device.map
are you running a livecd atm?
yes I was
what does /boot/grub/device.map say?
honestly I should tell you that I ultimately gave up and just installed ubuntu entirely on the Sata drive
well, that's probably for the best
so at this point I need to redo the installation again before I can get back at you
I suggest you wait till 9.10, when grub2 is the default.  Grub2 should detect your drives better
oh ok, but for the time being, should I just reconnect that second drive and look at the device.map file?
either way thanks for the information, much appreciated :)
if you want to hassle yourself, sure.  But grub2 will replace  grub, so it may not be worth it.
gotcha, I read up on GRUB 2 instead, didnt even know they were doing it
thanks again
